figure.head: European end of my time line

body.p: What's left to say about the year 2022? I survived it, as did most of those near and dear to me. Despite coming close several times, the UK's current apology for a government did not entirely collapse. As both the rest of this text and the above graphic attest, I spent much of the year trying to avoid thinking about the government by travelling. (Each red spot is a location where Mr Google spotted me.) I also spent quite a lot of time engaged on grand-parenting duties, of course.

list.item: In January and February, I seem to have done a lot of running about between dentists and doctors. I also paid my Covid dues and stayed in bed for a few days. I even did some work, trying my best to contribute something sensible to the CLS WG3 project on counting "verbs of inner life".
In March I went to Galway for three weeks, nervously clutching a prestigious CLS INFRA fellowship to test my brief (but very enjoyable) reincarnation as an itinerant scholar.

In May I went, as usual, to Tours to teach TEI "niveau 2", and then to La Vergne where I stayed until June, with the exception of a brief side trip to Nottingham to enjoy a Belinda concert and collect Lilette.
In June Lilette returned to Bristol and I went to Lyon to teach at an ENS summer school: it was very hot and the journey home was somewhat stressful.
In July, after a quick dash back to Oxford for dental and other purposes, I fitted in another brief visit to Galway to wrap up my fellowship alas.
In August we escaped to La Vergne again: in good time for both the Fete de Saint Syphorien and an unexpected outing.

In mid-September, I reluctantly came back to the UK, to attend (and address) the annual TEI conference, this year hosted by the University of Newcastle. Check out session 6B for an audio (but not alas video) recording of the session in which I held forth. Pompous, moi?

At the end of October, we celebrated (a bit early) our golden wedding anniversary with an extraordinary family holiday in the Forest of Dean. As well as many meals, some country walks, and much rushing about by Mr and Mrs Shiny, this featured four talks on family history by me, one for each of five decades. Many photos were taken.

In November I managed to fit in another escape to France, comprising a week in La Vergne, three days teaching TEI Level 1 in Tours, a day off to inspect a well known cathedral, and a day long meeting in Paris, before joining Lilette for a three week break in Mauritius, not before time.

body.p: Minute details of where and when are all logged in my Google Location History, but I don't know how to share that, other than by the occasional screen shot. But there are links to more detailed reportage of various kinds in the above list.
